UV Irradiation—Cultures were UV-irradiated in DGCthy media in Petri dishes on a rotating orbital shaker using a Sylvania 15-W germicidal light bulb (254 nm; 0.9 J/m2/s). Density Labeling of Replicated DNA—A fresh overnight culture was diluted 1:100 and grown in Davis minimal media with 0.4% glucose, 0.2% casamino acids, and 10 μg/ml thymine (DGCthy media) supplemented with [14C]thymine (0.1 μCi/ml) to an A600 of 0.45 in a 37 °C shaking water bath. The culture was then split into two halves and either mock UV-irradiated or UV-irradiated with 27 J/m2, before the cells were filtered on general filtration 0.45-μm membranes (Fisher-brand) and resuspended in DGC media containing 20 μg/ml 5-bromouracil in place of thymine and 0.5 μCi/ml of [3H]thymine (60.5 Ci/mmol). Cultures were allowed to recover for 1 h at 37 °C in a shaking water bath. Then, two volumes of ice-cold NET buffer (100 mm NaCl, 10 mm EDTA, 10 mm Tris, pH 8.0) were added. Cells were pelleted, resuspended in 150 μl of TE buffer (10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA, pH 8.0) and lysed by the addition of 150 μlK2HPO4/KOH (pH 12.5) and 20 μlof20% sarcosyl. The lysate was then subjected to isopycnic alkaline CsCl gradient centrifugation by combining 0.3 g lysate, 3.31 g 0.1 m K2HPO4/KOH (pH 12.5), and 2.23 g CsCl (refractive index = 1.4055) in a 5-ml polyallomer tube and centrifuged to equilibrium. Gradient fractions were collected on Whatman No. 17 paper, precipitated in 5% trichloroacetic acid, washed in 95% ethanol, and the amount of 14C and 3H in each fraction was quantitated in a scintillation counter. Degradation Assay—A fresh overnight culture was diluted 1:100 and grown in DGCthy media supplemented with [14C]thymine (0.1 μCi/ml) to an A600 of 0.4 in a 37 °C shaking incubator. Cultures were then pulse-labeled with 1 μCi/ml [3H]thymidine for 10 s (to label the nascent DNA at the replication fork) before being filtered on 0.45-μm membranes (Fisherbrand General Filtration), washed with 2–5 ml of NET buffer, resuspended in prewarmed non-radioactive DGCthy media, UV-irradiated with 27 J/m2, and then incubated in a 37 °C shaking incubator. Duplicate 200-μl aliquots of the culture (triplicate at time 0) were collected at 20-min intervals and lysed/precipitated in cold 5% trichloroacetic acid before being filtered on Millipore glass fiber prefilters. The amount of radioactivity in each filter was determined in a scintillation counter. Two-dimensional Gel and Southern Analysis—Fresh overnight cultures of cells that contain the plasmid pBR322 were grown in the presence of 100 μg/ml ampicillin. The overnight cultures were diluted 1:100 and grown without ampicillin selection in a shaking incubator at 37 °C to an A600 of 0.5 (∼5 × 108 cells/ml) and UV-irradiated with 50 J/m2. At the indicated time points, 0.75-ml samples were placed into 0.75 ml of cold 2× NET (100 mm NaCl, 10 mm Tris, pH 8.0, 10 mm EDTA). Each sample was pelleted, resuspended in 150 μl of 1 mg/ml lysozyme and 0.2 mg/ml RNaseA in TE buffer, and lysed at 37 °C for 20 min. At this time, proteinase K (10 μl, 10 mg/mg) and sarcosyl (10 μl, 20%) were added and incubated at 50 °C for 1 h. Samples were then extracted, twice, with four volumes of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25/24/1), once with four volumes of chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (24/1), and dialyzed for 3 h on 47-mm Whatman 0.05-μm pore disks (VMWP04700, Whatman Bioscience) floating on a 250-ml beaker of TE. Samples were then digested with PvuII (New England Biolabs), extracted with chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (24/1), and equal volumes were loaded onto the gel. Restricted genomic DNA samples were run in the first dimension in 0.4% agarose, 1× Tris-borate-EDTA at 1 volume/cm. Gel lanes were cut out, recast, and run in the second dimension in 1.0% agarose, 1× Tris-borate-EDTA at 6.5 volumes/cm. Gels were transferred to Hybond N+ nylon membranes and probed with pBR322 that had been labeled with 32P by nick translation according to the protocol supplied by Promega using [α-32P]dCTP (ICN Biomedicals). Radioactivity was visualized and quantitated with a Storm 820 PhosphorImager and its associated ImageQuant Software (Molecular Dynamics). RecO Is Required to Resume Replication After UV-induced DNA Damage—Both recF and recR are required for the recovery of replication after disruption by UV-induced DNA damage (5Courcelle J. Carswell-Crumpton C. Hanawalt P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 3714-3719Google Scholar). The ability of recO to recover replication after UV irradiation was compared with that of recF and recR and visualized by density-labeling the post-irradiation DNA synthesis with 5-bromouracil. Cultures that were either UV-irradiated with 27 J/m2 or mock-irradiated were allowed to recover for a period of one hour in media containing 5-bromouracil in place of thymine, so that any DNA replicated during this period would be of a greater density than the DNA synthesized before irradiation. The denser, replicated DNA in each culture was then separated from the rest of the DNA by centrifugation in isopycnic alkaline CsCl gradients and quantitated. As shown in Fig. 1, one hour after irradiation, UV-irradiated wild-type cells had replicated nearly as much DNA as their unirradiated counterparts, demonstrating that replication had fully recovered within this time frame. However, the amount of DNA synthesized in either recF, recR, or recO mutants was inhibited to a similar extent after this dose of UV irradiation. By contrast, although both recJ and recQ process the nascent DNA after UV irradiation (16Courcelle J. Hanawalt P.C. Mol. Gen. Gent. 1999; 262: 543-551Google Scholar) and affect the time that replication recovers, 1K.-H. Chow and J. Courcelle, unpublished observations. these genes are not essential for replication to resume, and significant amounts of DNA synthesis are observed in the absence of these gene products. It is of interest to note that, in an otherwise wild-type background, mutations in recJ or recQ do not render cells sensitive to UV irradiation (29Lovett S.T. Clark A.J. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 157: 190-196Google Scholar, 30Nakayama H. Nakayama K. Nakayama R. Irino N. Nakayama Y. Hanawalt P.C. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1984; 195: 474-480Google Scholar). The lack of recovery in recF and recR mutants is associated with a failure to maintain replication forks blocked by DNA damage. This can be visualized by examining the structural intermediates that are associated with arrested replication forks on plasmids such as pBR322 using two-dimensional agarose gel analysis (17Courcelle J. Donaldson J.R. Chow K.H. Courcelle C.T. Science. 2003; 299: 1064-1067Google Scholar, 31Friedman K.L. Brewer B.J. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 613-627Google Scholar). To determine whether recO mutants also fail to maintain the replication fork, we characterized the structural intermediates that occurred on replicating plasmid molecules of pBR322 after UV irradiation with 50 J/m2 in growing E. coli cultures. Previous studies by our group (17Courcelle J. Donaldson J.R. Chow K.H. Courcelle C.T. Science. 2003; 299: 1064-1067Google Scholar) have shown that this dose produces 0.5 lesions per plasmid strand and that 90% of the parental cells survive the irradiation to form colonies. Cells containing the plasmid pBR322 were UV-irradiated, and the genomic DNA was purified, digested with PvuII (which cuts the plasmid just downstream of the unidirectional origin of replication), and analyzed by two-dimensional agarose gels at the times indicated. In this technique, nonreplicating plasmids migrate as linear 4.4-kb fragments, whereas replicating fragments form Y-shaped structures and migrate more slowly because of their larger size and nonlinear shape. These replicating fragments form an arc that extends out from the linear fragment (Fig. 2A). In wild-type cells, a transient reversal of the replication fork has been shown to occur on plasmids after UV irradiation (17Courcelle J. Donaldson J.R. Chow K.H. Courcelle C.T. Science. 2003; 299: 1064-1067Google Scholar). The regressed fork intermediate is maintained by the RecF, RecR, and RecA proteins until a time that correlates with the removal of the lesions by nucleotide excision repair and the recovery of replication. The extrusion of the nascent DNA converts the three-arm replication fork structure into a four-arm, replication intermediate that further retards its mobility in the gel. These four-arm structures migrate in a cone region beyond the normal replication arc (Fig. 2A). Consistent with our previous studies, UV-irradiated recF and recR mutants did not accumulate the cone region intermediates to any significant extent (17Courcelle J. Donaldson J.R. Chow K.H. Courcelle C.T. Science. 2003; 299: 1064-1067Google Scholar). When we examined the replicating plasmids in UV-irradiated recO mutants, the replication fork intermediate also failed to accumulate (Fig. 2B), indicating that RecO, like RecF and RecR, is required to maintain the replication fork after arrest by UV-induced DNA damage. RecO Is Required with RecF and RecR to Protect the Nascent DNA at Blocked Replication Forks from Degradation by RecQ and RecJ—The failure to recover replication in UV-irradiated recF or recR mutants is associated with the extensive loss of nascent DNA made just prior to irradiation (5Courcelle J. Carswell-Crumpton C. Hanawalt P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 3714-3719Google Scholar). The failure of recO mutants to recover replication could indicate that RecO is required at a step similar to RecF and RecR and is needed to limit the nascent DNA degradation. Alternatively, RecO could be required at a subsequent step in the recovery process once the nascent DNA strands have been stabilized or protected. To differentiate between these possibilities, we examined the nascent degradation pattern in recO mutants. To this end, exponentially growing, [14C]thymine-prelabeled cultures were pulse-labeled with [3H]thymidine for 10 s to label the DNA at replication forks. Then, the culture was transferred to nonradioactive medium and immediately UV-irradiated with 27 J/m2. The 14C prelabel allowed us to compare the degradation occurring in the overall genome to that in the 3H-labeled DNA made at replication forks just prior to UV irradiation. As shown previously, UV-irradiated wild-type cells degrade very little of their overall genomic DNA after irradiation. However, some limited degradation of the nascent DNA was detected at times prior to the recovery of replication (Fig. 3A; Refs. 4Courcelle J. Crowley D.J. Hanawalt P.C. J. Bacteriol. 1999; 181: 916-922Google Scholar, 5Courcelle J. Carswell-Crumpton C. Hanawalt P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 3714-3719Google Scholar, 32Hanawalt P. Brempelis I. Proceedings of the 7th International Congress of Biochemistry, August, 1967. Japanese Biochemical Society, Tokyo, Japan1967: 650Google Scholar). In contrast to the limited degradation in wild-type cells, recF or recR mutants degraded approximately half of the nascent DNA made just prior to UV irradiation (Fig. 3B). When the degradation pattern was examined in recO mutants, we found that the nascent DNA was extensively degraded, and that the extent of degradation was similar to that occurring in recF and recR mutants (Fig. 3B). The result indicates that, like RecF and RecR, RecO contributes to protecting the DNA at blocked replication forks in UV-irradiated cells. Although extensive degradation occurs in all three recF, recR, and recO single mutants, it is possible that these gene products protect different strands of the blocked replication fork in vivo. If this is the case, then we would predict that the nascent DNA degradation would increase when more than one of these gene products is absent. To examine this possibility, we examined the nascent DNA degradation in double mutants of recF recR, recF recO, and recR recO, as well as the corresponding recF recO recR triple mutant. All double mutants exhibited nascent degradation patterns that were similar in extent to the recF or recR single mutants (Fig. 4A). Furthermore, the nascent DNA degradation in the triple mutant was also limited to approximately half of the nascent DNA (Fig. 4B), suggesting that RecO functions together with RecF and RecR to protect the same strand (or structural aspect) of the blocked replication fork. If RecO acts together with RecF and RecR to protect the nascent lagging strand of the arrested replication fork, then the observed nascent DNA degradation should be dependent upon RecJ and RecQ (16Courcelle J. Hanawalt P.C. Mol. Gen. Gent. 1999; 262: 543-551Google Scholar). To test this idea, we examined the nascent DNA degradation in recO mutants that also lacked either the RecQ helicase or RecJ nuclease (Fig. 3B). Consistent with this idea, the nascent DNA degradation was reduced to a similar extent in recF, recR,or recO mutants when either RecJ or RecQ was inactivated (Fig. 5). These observations indicate that the nascent DNA degradation in recO, recF, and recR mutants results from the same enzymatic degradation of the lagging strand by RecJ and RecQ. RecF, RecO, and RecR are proposed to form an epistatic group based upon several shared biochemical and genetic characteristics. All three mutations render cells equally hypersensitive to UV irradiation, reduce the frequency of recombinant progeny in conjugation or transduction assays in recBC or recD backgrounds, and delay the induction of the SOS response after DNA damage (14Hegde S. Sandler S.J. Clark A.J. Madiraju M.V. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1995; 246: 254-258Google Scholar, 15Whitby M.C. Lloyd R.G. Mol. Gen. Gent. 1995; 246: 174-179Google Scholar, 23Kolodner R. Fishel R.A. Howard M. J. Bacteriol. 1985; 163: 1060-1066Google Scholar, 24Mahdi A.A. Lloyd R.G. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1989; 216: 503-510Google Scholar). A recent study suggested that the UV hypersensitivity of recO is associated with a delayed recovery of replication similar to recF and recR (33Rangarajan S. Woodgate R. Goodman M.F. Mol. Microbiol. 2002; 43: 617-628Google Scholar). The results presented here indicate that RecF, RecR, and RecO function together to maintain replication forks arrested by UV-induced DNA damage. In addition, all three proteins are required together to limit the degradation of the nascent lagging strand by RecJ and RecQ after UV irradiation. In vitro, all three proteins bind DNA, and RecO has been shown to promote annealing between homologous DNA strands (34Luisi-Deluca C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 236: 124-138Google Scholar). RecO and RecR promote RecA protein-mediated d-loop formation at the 5′ end of linear ssDNA and stabilize RecA filaments to prevent their disassembly (7Shan Q. Bork J.M. Webb B.L. Inman R.B. Cox M.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 519-540Google Scholar, 25Umezu K. Kolodner R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30005-30013Google Scholar). Complexes of RecF and RecR bind double-strand DNA and gapped DNA substrates and limit how far RecA filaments are able to extend into double-strand regions (35Webb B.L. Cox M.M. Inman R.B. Cell. 1997; 91: 347-356Google Scholar). Furthermore, the RecFOR proteins in combination have been shown to facilitate RecA loading onto gapped DNA substrates (12Umezu K. Chi N.W. Kolodner R.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 3875-3879Google Scholar, 36Morimatsu K. Kowalczykowski S.C. Mol. Cell. 2003; 11: 1337-1347Google Scholar). These in vitro characterizations are consistent with the in vivo observations that RecF, RecO, and RecR may recognize and bind to nascent DNA at blocked replication forks and serve to stabilize the RecA filaments at these regions, as proposed previously (5Courcelle J. Carswell-Crumpton C. Hanawalt P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 3714-3719Google Scholar, 37Courcelle J. Hanawalt P.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 8196-8202Google Scholar). The data presented here and in previous work indicate that binding by these proteins limits the nascent degradation on the lagging strand by the RecQ-RecJ helicase-nuclease in vivo (Fig. 5). However, to date, the binding and activity of these gene products has not been examined on replication fork-like structures in vitro. A role for RecF, RecO, and RecR in stabilizing RecA filaments at blocked replication forks is also consistent with several genetic observations. recF, recO, and recR mutants exhibit a delayed SOS induction (14Hegde S. Sandler S.J. Clark A.J. Madiraju M.V. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1995; 246: 254-258Google Scholar, 15Whitby M.C. Lloyd R.G. Mol. Gen. Gent. 1995; 246: 174-179Google Scholar). Because RecA filaments bound to single-strand DNA function as the inducing signal for up-regulation of the SOS genes, the delay in up-regulation of SOS genes may reflect the reduced ability of RecA to bind to the replication fork substrates in the absence of RecFOR. Additionally, certain mutant alleles of RecA that increase its affinity to bind DNA are able to partially bypass the requirement for RecFOR and partially suppress the UV sensitivity of recF, recR, and recO mutants (38Madiraju M.V. Lavery P.E. Kowalczykowski S.C. Clark A.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 10529-10535Google Scholar, 39Madiraju M.V. Templin A. Clark A.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 6592-6596Google Scholar, 40Wang T.C. Chang H.Y. Hung J.L. Mutat. Res. 1993; 294: 157-166Google Scholar). To incorporate these observations, we have placed RecFOR at the nascent lagging strand junction of the block replication fork (Fig. 6). However, the precise arrangement and stoichiometry of this complex will require further investigation, and it remains possible that RecF, RecO, and RecR independently bind and recognize different portions of the replication fork structure to achieve its task of limiting the nascent lagging strand degradation and of stabilizing RecA filaments at arrested replication fork structures. This possibility is supported by genetic studies that show overexpression of RecR or RecO alone can partially suppress the UV sensitivity of recF mutants (41Sandler S.J. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1994; 245: 741-749Google Scholar, 42Sandler S.J. Clark A.J. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 3661-3672Google Scholar). However, the stoichiometry and constitution of the functional complex (or complexes) on the nascent lagging strand remains an important aspect that has not yet been identified. It is clear from this and previous studies that these genes are required for maintenance of replication forks blocked at DNA lesions until a time corresponding to when the lesions are repaired and replication can resume. In the absence of DNA damage when replication is not frequently disrupted, inactivation of RecF, RecO, or RecR does not seem to affect the growth rate or viability of growing E. coli cultures. However, in the event that replication arrests before the duplication of the genome has been completed, RecF, RecO, and RecR play a critical role in recognizing arrested fork structures as a proper substrate and in facilitating the stabilization of the RecA filament to protect and promote the resumption of replication, thereby allowing the processive duplication of the chromosome to be completed. We thank Anthony Poteete and Susan Rosenberg for providing bacterial strains used in this study.

The receptor Tyro3 together with Axl and Mer form the Axl/Tyro3 family of receptor tyrosine kinases. Members of this family play essential roles in spermatogenesis, immunoregulation, and phagocytosis. Gas6, the product of growth arrest-specific gene, activates the kinase activity of all three receptors. Here, we report the first biochemical and structural characterization of a member of this family, namely of a fragment spanning the two N-terminal Ig domains of the extracellular part of human Tyro3. Its ligand binding specificity profile is identical to the activation profile of the native receptor. The 1.95-Å crystal structure suggests a common ligand-binding site in this receptor family located at the interface of the Ig domains and unusually rich in cis-prolines. Furthermore, both in the crystal and in solution we observed the ligand-independent dimerization of the receptor fragment. This homophilic interaction emphasizes previous functional reports, which hinted that in addition to signal transduction, members of this family of receptors might participate in cell adhesion. Its ligand binding specificity profile is identical to the activation profile of the native receptor. The 1.95-Å crystal structure suggests a common ligand-binding site in this receptor family located at the interface of the Ig domains and unusually rich in cis-prolines. Furthermore, both in the crystal and in solution we observed the ligand-independent dimerization of the receptor fragment. Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) 1The abbreviations used are: RTK, receptor tyrosine kinase; FNIII, fibronectin type III; Ig, immunoglobulin-like; LG, laminin G-like; Tyro3-D1D2, a fragment spanning the N-terminal two Ig domains of the human Tyro3 receptor (residues 1-182); MAD, multiple wavelength anomalous dispersion. 1The abbreviations used are: RTK, receptor tyrosine kinase; FNIII, fibronectin type III; Ig, immunoglobulin-like; LG, laminin G-like; Tyro3-D1D2, a fragment spanning the N-terminal two Ig domains of the human Tyro3 receptor (residues 1-182); MAD, multiple wavelength anomalous dispersion. play key roles in cell regulation. Signaling through these receptors induces cell proliferation, differentiation, migration, and metabolism (1Ullrich A. Schlessinger J. Cell. 1990; 61: 203-212Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4580) Google Scholar). A little characterized group of RTKs is the Axl/Tyro3 family of receptors. The members of this family are Axl (also named Ark, Ufo, Tyro7) (2O'Bryan J.P. Frye R.A. Cogswell P.C. Neubauer A. Kitch B. Prokop C. Espinosa III, R. Le Beau M.M. Earp H.S. Liu E.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 5016-5031Crossref PubMed Scopus (625) Google Scholar, 3Rescigno J. Mansukhani A. Basilico C. Oncogene. 1991; 6: 1909-1913PubMed Google Scholar), Tyro3 (Sky, Rse, Brt, Dtk, Tif) (4Lai C. Gore M. Lemke G. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 2567-2578PubMed Google Scholar, 5Mark M.R. Scadden D.T. Wang Z. Gu Q. Goddard A. Godowski P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10720-10728Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and Mer (Nyk, c-Eyk, Tyro12) (6Graham D.K. Dawson T.L. Mullaney D.L. Snodgrass H.R. Earp H.S. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 647-657PubMed Google Scholar, 7Jia R. Hanafusa H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 1839-1844Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). They share a distinct molecular structure, and from the N terminus their extracellular part consists of two immunoglobulin-like domains (Ig domains) followed by two fibronectin-type III repeats (FNIII domains). The membrane-spanning single helix is followed by the cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase domain. The three family members are widely expressed in adult tissues, most prominently in the brain, testis, lymphatic, and vascular system (8Crosier K.E. Crosier P.S. Pathology. 1997; 29: 131-135Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Overexpression has also been observed in a variety of cancers including mammary tumors (9Taylor I.C. Roy S. Varmus H.E. Oncogene. 1995; 11: 2619-2626PubMed Google Scholar), leukemia (2O'Bryan J.P. Frye R.A. Cogswell P.C. Neubauer A. Kitch B. Prokop C. Espinosa III, R. Le Beau M.M. Earp H.S. Liu E.T. Mol. Cancer. 2001; 37: 2264-2274Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar).The precise physiological function of each individual member of this family is still under debate. A number of different phenotypes are observed in mice lacking individual or all three receptors. For example, Mer-truncated mice develop blindness because of postnatal degeneration of the photoreceptors. Mice lacking all three receptors are infertile because of the destruction of the germ cells (11Lu Q. Gore M. Zhang Q. Camenisch T. Boast S. Casagranda F. Lai C. Skinner M.K. Klein R. Matsushima G.K. Earp H.S. Goff S.P. Lemke G. Nature. 1999; 398: 723-728Crossref PubMed Scopus (386) Google Scholar). Costa M. Lin D.A. Basilico C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 614-625Crossref PubMed Google Scholar).To shed light onto the molecular mechanisms by which this important family of receptors exerts its functions, we investigated the atomic structure of the Tyro3 receptor. We report the crystal structure of the N-terminal Ig domain pair of Tyro3 and show that this fragment binds the ligand Gas6 and displays the identical binding specificity profile as the full-length mature receptor. The crystal structure suggests the existence of a common ligand-binding site in the Axl/Tyro3 receptors, located close to the interface of the Ig domains. Furthermore the existence of ligand-independent receptor dimers both in the crystal and in solution explains a number of previous observations regarding the function of these receptors.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESProtein Production—The DNA encoding for the extracellular domain of the human Tyro3 receptor was amplified by PCR from a cDNA pool of human adult brain, kindly obtained from Regina Reszka (Max Delbrück Center, Berlin, Germany). A fragment of the Tyro3 gene encoding for residues 1-182 (numbering of the residues in the mature protein is according to Swiss Protein Database entry Q06418, named hereafter Tyro3-D1D2) was cloned into a pET21a+ expression vector (Novagen, Madison, WI) using restriction sites NdeI and XhoI. The correctness of the construct was confirmed by DNA sequencing.Following transformation into the methionine-auxotroph Escherichia coli strain B834(DE3), unlabeled protein was produced in LB medium at 37 °C upon induction with 1 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside for 3 h. Selenomethionine-labeled protein was produced as described (30Budisa N. Steipe B. Demange P. Eckerskorn C. Kellermann J. Huber R. Eur J Biochem. 1995; 230: 788-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar). Cells were grown in minimal medium overnight to an A600nm = 0.6, harvested, and washed three times with medium containing selenomethionine instead of methionine. The cells were resuspended in selenomethionine-containing medium and cultivated for 2 h, and protein expression was induced for 10 h with 1 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside.The bacterial pellet was sonicated in 20 mm Tris-buffer, pH 7.5, containing 5 mm EDTA. Inclusion bodies were isolated by centrifugation, washed, and resolved in 20 mm Tris buffer, pH 8, 6 m guanidine hydrochloride, and 4 mm dithiothreitol. The concentration of the protein was adjusted to 1 mg/ml (estimated from UV absorbance), and refolding conditions were identified using the FSAP method (31Heiring C. Muller Y.A. Protein Eng. 2001; 14: 183-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Large scale refolding was accomplished by rapid dilution of the solubilized protein into a buffer containing 20 mm Tris buffer, pH 8, and 10 mm cysteine followed by overnight incubation at 4 °C.The Tyro3-D1D2 fragment was purified with a HR Q-Sepharose chromatography column (Amersham Biosciences) equilibrated with 20 mm Tris buffer, pH 8, and eluted with a 0-1 m NaCl gradient. The fractions containing Tyro3-D1D2 were concentrated using Ultrafree Concentrators (Millipore, Billerica, MA) and further purified by gel filtration on a Superdex 75 column (Amersham Biosciences) with a buffer containing 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8, 150 mm NaCl. This protocol yielded about 10-15 mg of pure protein/liter of cell culture.Site-directed mutations were introduced in a two-step protocol. First, two overlapping fragments were amplified with PCR using the pET21a+:Tyro3-D1D2 plasmid as a template. The first fragment was obtained by combining the original forward primer with a reverse primer containing the desired mutation, and for the second fragment a mutated forward primer was used together with the original reverse primer. Second, the two purified PCR products were fused to each other in a single denaturing/annealing cycle and reamplified using the original forward and reverse primers only. Subsequently the fragment was subcloned into a pET21a+ vector, and the presence of the desired mutation was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Pure mutant protein was produced using the protocol established for the wild type protein.Biochemical Characterization—Analytical size exclusion chromatography of Gas6-LG, human, or bovine protein S alone or in combination with Tyro3-D1D2 was performed at 4 °C with a Superose 6 column (Amersham Biosciences) attached to an Äkta Purifier (Amersham Biosciences) equilibrated with a running buffer containing 20 mm Tris, pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, and 5 mm CaCl2 at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min. 100-μl protein samples loaded onto the column contained either 70 μg of Gas6-LG, human protein S, or bovine protein S or 30 μg of Tyro3-D1D2 as a reference, as well as mixtures of Gas6-LG/Tyro3-D1D2 (70 μg/50 μg), bovine protein S/Tyro3-D1D2 (70 μg/30 μg), or human protein S/Tyro3-D1D2 (70 μg/30 μg) roughly corresponding to a 1:1.5 molar ratio. Gel filtration experiments in which the three Tyro3-D1D2 mutants were compared with wild type Tyro3-D1D2 were performed with a Superdex 75 column (Amersham Biosciences) at a flow rate of 1 ml/min.The self-association behavior of Tyro3-D1D2 wild type and of mutant I59R was further investigated by analytical ultracentrifugation with a Beckman XL-I centrifuge (Beckman Coulter). Radial absorbance data sets at 280 nm and at two different protein concentrations (0.2 and 0.75 mg/ml) were collected at four different angular speeds (15,000, 25,000, 35,000, and 42,000 rpm) for Tyro3-D1D2 wild type and at two different speeds (15,000 and 25,000 rpm) for mutant I59R. Data were analyzed with the Origin6/XL-I package (Beckman), and best fits between model and data obtained with a monomer dimer self-association model. The dissociation constant (KD) for the wild type protein is 30 μm and greater than 15 mm for mutant I59R.Crystallization and X-ray Structure Determination—Single crystals of the Tyro3-D1D2 fragment suitable for x-ray analysis were grown by using the hanging drop method and mixing 2 μl of protein solution (17 mg/ml, 20 mm HEPES buffer, pH 7.0) with 1 μl of precipitant solution (100 mm sodium cacodylate, pH 5.4-5.7, 10-14% polyethylene glycol 2000, 200 mm magnesium acetate, and 4 mm dithiothreitol) over 700 μl of reservoir solution (100 mm sodium cacodylate, pH 5.5, 12% polyethylene glycol 2000, 200 mm magnesium acetate). Crystals with sizes of about 150 × 70 × 70 μm3 grow at 20 °C within a week and have a hexagonal cross-section. Prior to data collection, for cryoprotection the crystals were soaked in a reservoir solution in which the polyethylene glycol 400 concentration was increased stepwise to 30% (w/v). Native data were collected on a CuKα rotating anode equipped with a Rigaku Raxis IV+ image plate system. Multiple wavelength anomalous dispersion (MAD) data were collected at three different wavelengths (peak, inflection point, and remote) at beamline BW7a at the EMBL Outstation in Hamburg, Germany. The data were reduced with program XDS (32Kabsch W. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 1988; 24: 916-924Crossref Scopus (1681) Google Scholar).Initial phases were obtained in space group P61 with the program SOLVE/RESOLVE (33Terwilliger T.C. Berendzen J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1999; 55: 849-861Crossref PubMed Scopus (3219) Google Scholar) and further improved with solvent flattening and NCS averaging. An initial model spanning residues 7-182 was built manually with program O (34Jones T.A. Zou J.Y. Cowan S.W. Kjeldgaard Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1991; 47: 110-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (13003) Google Scholar) and contained most of the side chains apart from two loop regions in the first Ig domain (residues 43-46 and 80-84). Here only the Cα backbone could be traced. After an initial round of refinement against the MAD data set, the model was refined against the 1.95-Å native data set using the simulated annealing and energy minimization protocol of the crystallography software (CNS) (35Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16929) Google Scholar). Following the introduction of water molecules, model refinement was continued with the program REFMAC (36Murshudov G.N. Vagin A.A. Dodson E.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1997; 53: 240-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (13774) Google Scholar). Each round of automatic refinement was followed by the inspection of the σA-weighted electron density maps (37Read R.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1986; 42: 140-149Crossref Scopus (2035) Google Scholar) and the manual rebuilding of the model. Rfree was monitored to assess model refinement progress.The final model consists of the two molecules of Tyro3-D1D2 present in the asymmetric unit (residues Gly7-Gln182), 276 water molecules, 1 zinc ion (probably introduced as an impurity during crystallization) as well as four acetates and one HEPES molecule present in the crystallization buffer. Four residues in molecule A (Gln30, Ile59, Phe61, His180) and six residues in molecule B (His57, Ile59, Phe61, Lys65, Ser66, Glu96) are modeled with two alternative side chain conformations. Open table in a new tab RESULTSFunctional Characterization of Tyro3-D1D2—A fragment containing the first two Ig domains of the human Tyro3 receptor (residues 1-182) was tested by analytical size exclusion chromatography for its ability to bind to its physiological ligand Gas6 as well as to the proteins bovine and human protein S. The elution profiles (Fig. 1, A-C) of each of these putative binding partners alone and mixed with Tyro3-D1D2 in a molar ratio of 1:1.5 show that the addition of Tyro3-D1D2 to Gas6-LG causes the formation of a complex, as revealed by a clearly visible shift of the Gas6 peak toward higher molecular weights when compared with Gas6 alone.The same behavior is observed when mixing bovine protein S and Tyro3-D1D2. A sample collected from this higher molecular weight peak analyzed by SDS-PAGE confirms the formation of the complex (data not shown). In contrast to bovine protein S, no complex is formed upon the addition of human protein S to Tyro3-D1D2. In this case the elution profile of the mixture resembles the overlaid profiles of the two reference samples.These experiments show that both Gas6 and bovine protein S bind to Tyro3-D1D2. Moreover, Tyro3-D1D2 is capable of discriminating between bovine and human protein S, and thus this truncated fragment displays the same binding specificity profile as reported for the native human Tyro3 receptor (27Godowski P.J. Mark M.R. Chen J. Sadick M.D. Raab H. Hammonds R.G. Cell. 1995; 82: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar).To further characterize the fragment, we performed analytical ultracentrifugation experiments. Radial absorbance data sets from samples containing different protein concentrations were collected at sedimentation equilibrium at different speeds. Data evaluation using a model with single ideal species resulted in an average molecular mass of 31 kDa (the nominal molecular mass of Tyro3-D1D2 calculated from the sequence is 19.6 kDa). In this model the apparent molecular mass increased with the centrifugal radius, indicating the presence of higher aggregates. A significantly better fit is obtained applying a self-association model and assuming a dimer monomer equilibrium. The calculated dissociation constant of the dimer monomer equilibrium is 30 μm.Crystal Structure of Tyro3-D1D2—Well diffracting crystals of the Tyro3-D1D2 fragment belong to space group P61 and contain two Tyro3-D1D2 fragments in the asymmetric unit. The crystal structure was solved by the MAD method and the model refined at 1.95 Å resolution to a crystallographic R-factor of 21.3%. The polypeptide chain of the fragment can be traced uninterruptedly in the electron density from residues Gly7 to Gln182. The first six residues are disordered and therefore are not visible in the electron density maps.The overall structure of Tyro3-D1D2 (Fig. 2A) consists of two immunoglobulin-like domains, in agreement with the modular architecture predicted from the amino acid sequence. In the full-length receptor, the polypeptide chain would then protrude from the C terminus of the fragment leading to the two membrane proximal FNIII repeats. The N-terminal Ig domain consists of residues 7-96 and belongs to the I-set of Ig domains (38Harpaz Y. Chothia C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 238: 528-539Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar). Its closest structural homologue is telokin (39Holden H.M. Ito M. Hartshorne D.J. Rayment I. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 227: 840-851Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). A remarkable feature can be observed in the G-strand; instead of solely contributing to the AGFCC′ sheet, it starts as a short G′-strand (residues 86-88) hydrogen-bonded to strand B of the DEB sheet. Upon interruption of this sheet extension by a β-bulge the polypeptide chain crosses over to become part of the AGFCC′ sheet (residues 91-96). Such a sheet crossover does not occur in other Ig domains of the I-set as classified by the SCOP (structural classification of proteins) data base (40Hubbard T.J. Murzin A.G. Brenner S.E. Chothia C. Nucleic. Acids Res. 1997; 25: 236-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar) and to the best of our knowledge has not been observed in any other Ig superfamily domain fold so far. The second Ig domain spans residues 97-182, and strand A starts at residue 100. This domain belongs to the C2-set of the Ig domains. Its closest structural neighbor is the third extracellular Ig domain of fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (41Plotnikov A.N. Schlessinger J. Hubbard S.R. Mohammadi M. Cell. 1999; 98: 641-650Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (502) Google Scholar).Fig. 2Monomer structure and surface conservation. A, schematic representation of the Tyro3-D1D2 monomer. The first domain (D1) belongs to the I-set of Ig domains and features a unique crossing over of the G-strand between the DEB and the AGFCC′ sheet. The second domain (D2) belongs to the C2-set. B, mapping of conserved residues (yellow patches) onto the surface of Tyro3-D1D2, displayed in two different orientations. C, sequence alignment of the three human Axl/Tyro3 family members spanning the N-terminal two Ig domains. The β-sheet structure of Tyro3-D1D2 is indicated by green arrows. Conserved residues are highlighted in yellow; and residues involved in the dimerization interface are marked with black boxes. Molecular sketches were generated with PyMol (Delano Scientific, San Carlos, CA).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)The two Ig domains are linked together in an extended orientation. An angle of 139° is formed between the Cα atom of Glu96 from the linker region and the centers of mass of the two Ig domains. Inspection of the domain interface shows that the orientation of the domains is stabilized by an intricate network of hydrogen bonds (Fig. 3A). These interactions are likely to provide some rigidity in the overall arrangement of the two domains. This rigidity is confirmed by the observation that the domain orientation is similar in the two molecules of Tyro3-D1D2 present in the asymmetric unit of the crystal. When the entire molecules are superimposed, the root mean square deviation value between the Cα atoms of both molecules in the asymmetric unit is 0.793 Å. Only slightly lower values are obtained when the N-terminal and C-terminal Ig domains are superimposed separately (0.201 Å and 0.483Å). We therefore expect that the extended orientation observed for the first two Ig domains of the Tyro3 receptor is not a result of the crystal packing but prevails in receptor molecules displayed on the cell surface.Fig. 3Structural details in the Tyro3-D1D2 monomer. A, stereoview of the interface between the first and second Ig domains of Tyro3-D1D2. Hydrogen bonds are displayed as yellow dots. The linker segment is shown in an all atom main chain representation and the remaining parts as Cα sketches. The high number of interactions across the interface suggests a rigid orientation of the domains. B, stereoview of the cis-proline-rich BC and C′E loops of the second Ig domain.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Characterization and Mutational Confirmation of the Dimerization Interface—To correlate the ultracentrifugation results with the crystal structure, we inspected the crystal packing of Tyro3-D1D2 for the presence of preformed dimers. Two possible dimerization modes were identified based on extended monomer-monomer interface contacts. In these dimers, the monomers are related by non-crystallographic 2-fold symmetry. The first dimer is formed through contacts mediated by the N-terminal Ig domain, and the con

The recombinational properties of long GAA·TTC repeating sequences were analyzed in Escherichia coli to gain further insights into the molecular mechanisms of the genetic instability of this tract as possibly related to the etiology of Friedreich's ataxia. Intramolecular and intermolecular recombination studies showed that the frequency of recombination between the GAA·TTC tracts was as much as 15 times higher than the non-repeating control sequences. Homologous, intramolecular recombination between GAA·TTC tracts and GAAGGA·TCCTTC repeats also occurred with a very high frequency (∼0.8%). Biochemical analyses of the recombination products demonstrated the expansions and deletions of the GAA·TTC repeats. These results, together with our previous studies on the CTG·CAG sequences, suggest that the recombinational hot spot characteristics may be a common feature of all triplet repeat sequences. Unexpectedly, we found that the recombination properties of the GAA·TTC tracts were unique, compared with CTG·CAG repeats, because they depended on the DNA secondary structure polymorphism. Increasing the length of the GAA·TTC repeats decreased the intramolecular recombination frequency between these tracts. Also, a correlation was found between the propensity of the GAA·TTC tracts to adopt the sticky DNA conformation and the inhibition of intramolecular recombination. The use of novobiocin to modulate the intracellular DNA topology, i.e. the lowering of the negative superhelical density, repressed the formation of the sticky DNA structure, thereby restoring the expected positive correlation between the length of the GAA·TTC tracts and the frequency of intramolecular recombination. Hence, our results demonstrate that sticky DNA exists and functions in E. coli. Intramolecular and intermolecular recombination studies showed that the frequency of recombination between the GAA·TTC tracts was as much as 15 times higher than the non-repeating control sequences. Biochemical analyses of the recombination products demonstrated the expansions and deletions of the GAA·TTC repeats. These results, together with our previous studies on the CTG·CAG sequences, suggest that the recombinational hot spot characteristics may be a common feature of all triplet repeat sequences. Unexpectedly, we found that the recombination properties of the GAA·TTC tracts were unique, compared with CTG·CAG repeats, because they depended on the DNA secondary structure polymorphism. Increasing the length of the GAA·TTC repeats decreased the intramolecular recombination frequency between these tracts. Also, a correlation was found between the propensity of the GAA·TTC tracts to adopt the sticky DNA conformation and the inhibition of intramolecular recombination. The use of novobiocin to modulate the intracellular DNA topology, i.e. the lowering of the negative superhelical density, repressed the formation of the sticky DNA structure, thereby restoring the expected positive correlation between the length of the GAA·TTC tracts and the frequency of intramolecular recombination. Microsatellites or short tandem repeats are DNA sequences composed of repetitive units of one to six nucleotides (1Weber J.L. Wong C. Hum. Mol. Genet. 1993; 2: 1123-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (1318) Google Scholar, 2Hearne C.M. Ghosh S. Todd J.A. Trends Genet. 1992; 8: 288-294Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (368) Google Scholar). These repetitive elements are highly abundant in many prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes (3Subramanian S. Madgula V.M. George R. Mishra R.K. Pandit M.W. Kumar C.S. Singh L. Bioinformatics. 2003; 19: 549-552Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 4Subramanian S. Mishra R.K. Singh L. Genome Biol. 2003; 4: R13Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Microsatellites compose ∼3% of the human genome. GAA·TTC repeats are one of the most ubiquitous short tandem repeats, among 10 possible trinucleotide sequences, in the human genome (3Subramanian S. Madgula V.M. George R. Mishra R.K. Pandit M.W. Kumar C.S. Singh L. Bioinformatics. 2003; 19: 549-552Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 4Subramanian S. Mishra R.K. Singh L. Genome Biol. 2003; 4: R13Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Microsatellites are highly polymorphic and can be found in all chromosomes in a variety of lengths (2Hearne C.M. Ghosh S. Todd J.A. Trends Genet. 1992; 8: 288-294Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (368) Google Scholar). Polypurine·polypyrimidine (poly(R·Y)) sequences, including GAA·TTC repeats, are frequently the longest repeating tracts in the human genome (3Subramanian S. Madgula V.M. George R. Mishra R.K. Pandit M.W. Kumar C.S. Singh L. Bioinformatics. 2003; 19: 549-552Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 4Subramanian S. Mishra R.K. Singh L. Genome Biol. 2003; 4: R13Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). GAA·TTC repeats are also very abundant in Alu elements (5Chauhan C. Dash D. Grover D. Rajamani J. Mukerji M. J. Biomol. Struct. Dyn. 2002; 20: 253-263Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). Poly(R·Y) repetitive DNA tracts have been extensively studied since the discovery of their potential to adopt unusual DNA conformations, primarily triplex structures (reviewed in Ref. 6Soyfer V.N. Potaman V.N. Triple-helical Nucleic Acids. Springer-Verlag, New York1996Crossref Google Scholar). These sequences may have several important biological functions in vivo. Polymorphism of the GAA·TTC repeats is responsible for the regulation of gene expression in Mycoplasma (7Liu L. Dybvig K. Panangala V.S. van Santen V.L. French C.T. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 871-876Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 8Glew M.D. Baseggio N. Markham P.F. Browning G.F. Walker I.D. Infect. Immun. 1998; 66: 5833-5841Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Here we evaluated the recombination propensity of GAA·TTC tracts in both intramolecular and intermolecular systems in E. coli. This GAA·TTC recombination study is the first demonstration of a structure-dependent hot spot activity of a DNA sequence. An intramolecular recombination system was developed in which a crossover event between direct repeats leads to the deletion of the intervening sequence, including the GFPuv gene, located between the repeats (Fig. 1C). This deletion results in white colony formation. In contrast, when the plasmid containing the GFPuv gene is established in the host cell, the expression of this gene leads to the formation of a fluorescent green colony. Thus, the frequency of the recombination events was measured as the ratio of the number of white colonies to the total number of viable cells. In order to study the frequency of intermolecular recombination between plasmids harboring the (GAA·TTC) repeats, derivatives of pBR322 containing different TRS lengths were transformed into E. coli AB1157 and ECF005 cells. This was followed by a second transformation with the pFW25 derivatives containing varying lengths of the (GAA·TTC) inserts (Fig. 1B). In E. coli ECF005, both plasmids can co-exist without recombining and can give rise to TetR and CmR colonies. These plasmids could also recombine to form co-integrants at a certain frequency. In order to establish the frequency of these recombination events, the (GAA·TTC)-containing pBR322 and pFW25 derivatives were sequentially transformed into E. coli AB1157. Because this was a two-step transformation, the pBR322 derivative was already established in the cell and could therefore exist independently in the presence of tetracycline. The pFW25 derivatives, however, cannot replicate in this strain because of the absence of the π protein (30Pluciennik A. Iyer R.R. Napierala M. Larson J.E. Filutowicz M. Wells R.D. J. Biol. GAA·TTC Tracts Are Preferred Sites for Intramolecular Recombination, but Long Sticky DNA Is Inhibitory—Plasmids pRW4876gfp, pRW4882gfp, and pRW4886gfp harboring pairs of 33, 60, and 176 GAA·TTC tracts, respectively (Fig. 1A), were transformed into E. coli AB1157, the parental strain. Two controls were used in these experiments as follows: pRW4819gfp containing a pair of (CTG·CAG)67 repeats and pRW4873gfp harboring a pair of non-repeating, 354-bp fragments of the DMPK gene (Fig. 1A). Fig. 2A shows that pRW4876gfp with two (GAA·TTC)33 tracts, oriented as direct repeats, recombined in E. coli AB1157 with a frequency ∼10 times higher than the plasmid carrying the non-repeating sequences (pRW4873gfp). In addition, pRW4876gfp had a much higher (1.5–60 times) propensity for intramolecular recombination than plasmids harboring tracts of 17, 67, 98, and 165 CTG·CAG repeats (29Napierala M. Parniewski P. Pluciennik A. Wells R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 34087-34100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar) (Fig. 2A). Surprisingly, the studies conducted with pRW4882gfp, carrying longer GAA·TTC tracts (of 60 repeats), showed a decrease in the frequency of intramolecular recombination from 12.6% for the plasmid with a pair of (GAA·TTC)33 repeats to 7.4% for pRW4882gfp. Moreover, a further increase in the length of the recombining sequences, up to 176 repeats, led to an even more dramatic suppression of recombination (Fig. 2A). Thus, increasing the length of the recombining sequences from 33 to 176 GAA·TTC repeats showed an ∼3-fold decrease in the recombination frequency. These results were confirmed by three independent experiments performed in E. coli AB1157. The same tendency was observed in another wild type E. coli strain, KMBL1001 (Fig. 3A, filled symbols). It should be pointed out that, in all cases, regardless of the length of the recombining sequences, the frequency of recombination between the GAA·TTC repeats was several times higher than for the non-repeating, control DMPK fragments (Fig. 2A). Thus, we conclude that GAA·TTC repeats per se are preferred sites (hot spots) for intramolecular recombination. In order to determine the cause of the inverse correlation between the frequency of recombination and the length of homologous sequences, a restriction analysis of the plasmids harboring GAA·TTC tracts was performed (Fig. 2B). In Neurospora crassa, several biological phenomena such as the synthesis of carotenoids in the mycelia and polarity of perithecia are regulated by light. We found that a sod-1 mutant, with a defective Cu,Zn-type superoxide dismutase (SOD), showed accelerated light-dependent induction of carotenoid accumulation in the mycelia compared with the wild type. The initial rate of light-induced carotenoid accumulation in the sod-1 mutant was faster than that in the vvd mutant known to accumulate high concentrations. This acceleration was suppressed by treatment with antioxidant reagents. Light-induced transcription of genes involved in carotenoid synthesis, al-1, -2, and -3, was sustained in the sod-1 mutant, whereas it was transient in the wild type. Moreover sod-1 was defective in terms of light-induced polarity of perithecia. By genetic analysis, the enhancement in light-inducible carotenoid synthesis in sod-1 was dependent on the wild type alleles of wc-1 and wc-2. However, the sod-1;vvd double mutant showed additive effects on the carotenoid accumulation in the mycelia. These results suggested that intracellular reactive oxygen species regulated by SOD-1 could affect the light-signal transduction pathway via WC proteins. This acceleration was suppressed by treatment with antioxidant reagents. Light-induced transcription of genes involved in carotenoid synthesis, al-1, -2, and -3, was sustained in the sod-1 mutant, whereas it was transient in the wild type. Moreover sod-1 was defective in terms of light-induced polarity of perithecia. By genetic analysis, the enhancement in light-inducible carotenoid synthesis in sod-1 was dependent on the wild type alleles of wc-1 and wc-2. However, the sod-1;vvd double mutant showed additive effects on the carotenoid accumulation in the mycelia. These results suggested that intracellular reactive oxygen species regulated by SOD-1 could affect the light-signal transduction pathway via WC proteins. Light is one of the most important environmental factors being utilized for various biological phenomena by living organisms (1Kendrich R.E. Kronenberg G.H.M. Photomorphogenesis in Plants. 2nd Ed. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Netherlands1994Crossref Google Scholar, 2Meyerowitz E.M. Somerville C.R. Arabidopsis. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1994Google Scholar). Typical examples are the visual systems in animals, photosynthesis in plants, and photomorphogenesis in fungi. In Neurospora crassa, several biological phenomena are under the control of blue light. Light-induced processes are summarized as follows: (i) synthesis of carotenoids in the mycelia (3Harding R.W. Turner R.V. Plant Physiol. 1981; 68: 745-749Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), (ii) induction of conidiation (3Harding R.W. Turner R.V. Plant Physiol. 1981; 68: 745-749Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), (iii) formation of protoperithecia on nitrogen-deficient media (4Degli-Innocenti F. Russo V.E. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 757-761Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), (vi) positive phototropism of perithecial beaks (5Harding R.W. Melles S. Plant Physiol. 1984; 72: 996-1000Crossref Google Scholar), (v) positioning of the beak formed on the perithecium (perithecial polarity) (6Oda K. Hasunuma K. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1997; 256: 593-601Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 7Ogura Y. Yoshida Y. Yabe N. Hasunuma K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 21228-21234Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar), and (vi) phase shift in the circadian rhythm of conidiation (8Sargent M.L. Briggs W.R. Plant Physiol. 1967; 42: 1504-1510Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Feldman J.F. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. 1982; 33: 583-608Crossref Google Scholar). Much information on photoreceptors and light-inducible genes has been accumulated by genetic and molecular biological analyses to understand the molecular mechanism of these photobiological phenomena. In the search for the blue light photoreceptor in N. crassa, light-insensitive mutants, white collar (wc) 1The abbreviations used are: wc, white collar; NDK-1, nucleoside diphosphate kinase-1; ROS, reactive oxygen species; SOD, superoxide dismutase; RT, reverse transcriptase; Pipes, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid. 1The abbreviations used are: wc, white collar; NDK-1, nucleoside diphosphate kinase-1; ROS, reactive oxygen species; SOD, superoxide dismutase; RT, reverse transcriptase; Pipes, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid.-1 and wc-2, deficient in most of these blue light responses, have been isolated (4Degli-Innocenti F. Both possess a PAS (PER, ARNT, and SIM) domain, a zinc finger DNA binding motif, and a glutamine-rich putative transcription activation domain (12Ballario P. Vittorioso P. Margrelli A. Talora C. Cabibbo A. Macino G. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1650-1657Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar, 13Linden H. Macino G. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 98-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar). Microbiol. 1998; 29: 719-729Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar, 15Cheng P. Yang Y. Gardner K.H. Liu Y. Mol. Cell. In Arabidopsis thaliana, three major groups of photoreceptors, phytochromes (16Quail P.H. Bioessays. 1997; 19: 571-579Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), cryptochromes (17Ahmad M. Jarillo J.A. Smirnova O. Cashmore A.R. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 939-948Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (263) Google Scholar), and phototropins (18Briggs W.R. Huala E. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Chem. 2001; 276: 11457-11460Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). WC-1 also has one LOV domain, which is a putative chromophore-binding site. The WC-1·WC-2 complex is reported to bind FAD (flavin-adenine dinucleotide) (20He Q. Cheng P. Yang Y. Wang L. Gardner K.H. Liu Y. Science. 2002; 297: 840-843Crossref PubMed Scopus (342) Google Scholar).
